body:
Tested with precise trackpad under FlatLaf, Windows Laf, Mac OS Laf, Metal and Nimbus.
Tested with not precise mouse wheel under FlatLaf, Windows Laf, Metal and Nimbus.
Closed in favor of [PR-4100](https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2059)

Please use the `datatypes.dtd` and `XMLSchema.dtd` files from:

- `ide/xml.catalog/src/org/netbeans/modules/xml/catalog/resources/datatypes.dtd`
- `ide/xml.catalog/src/org/netbeans/modules/xml/catalog/resources/XMLSchema.dtd`

Both have the W3C license attached, so that we don't need to discuss license headers everytime. That way all four copies in the source tree of the files will be identical.

Apart from that - great.
I've fixed the merge conflict in apichanges. Erik - it would be nice if this could be considered for 12. Thanks!

> 
> 
> Currently v5.5.0
> 
> The jgit project has recently released v5.7.0 but this has some API changes and AFAICS no compelling reason to upgrade.

Nothing to prevent acceptance of this, but does there need to be a new ticket to account for future upgrade and API changed for 5.7 (and/or greater when it happens)?

@ebarboni, it would be awesome if this could be considered for 12.0.

Thanks, Jan

Hello Hector, thanks for your interest in extending `Lookup` API. It is a core NetBeans API and I am still fond of creating it. That's one aspect.

The other one is that I don't understand why Java has `Optional`!? I believe I am not the only one. Java community seems to be divided into `Optional` believers and haters. I guess I fall rather into the latter category. To make it short, I have nothing against the believers using:
```java
Optional.of(context.lookup(AClass.class)).orElse(...)
```
but adding new method into `Lookup` and writing:
```java
context.lookupOptional(AClass.class).orElse(...)
```
isn't my cup of tea. Adding a new method into subclassable class isn't for free. Moreover please notice that both variants of the code are actually almost of the same length - e.g. I don't see any benefits in adding new `lookupOptional` method into `Lookup`.

That said, I am not going to veto the change, if there are at least three supporters of `Optional` in the `Lookup`. E.g. I am going to continue with the review, assuming you'll find enough supporters to overcome my own dislike of `Optional`.

Just a side note to this change, I think that the JavaPlatform.getProperties.get("platform.ant.name") would be worth to have it's own API in JavaPlatform like a String JavaPlatform.getInternalID().
Maybe it was not planned to be used and exposed that much, however it is "extensively" used in the code as a commonly know "secret trick".
Oh, BTW Gradle 6.3 is the first version supporting Java 14.
So should this be targeted to 12.0? Ups, just saw the label attached...
It might or may not be included in 12.0. Let's @ebarboni have that call.

@JaroslavTulach thank you for the advises and the approval! I'd consider to create a Node based model, though unfortunately, I'm in rush finishing the new Gradle project wizards for 12.0 (if the RM would allow to put that in). This thing is just a side work coming out of that.

BTW: Can I have your opinion on the "platform.ant.name" thing I mentioned earlier on this thread?

Unlike @jtulach I'll stick my head above the parapet as an `Optional` believer! :smile: And if `Lookup` was being written now I'd be very much in favour of building around `Optional` and particularly `Stream` (in fact have done so in my own take on the idea, and like JDK ServiceLoader additions).  However, I'm not in favour of retrofitting APIs just for the sake of it.  A mailing list discussion on pros, cons, reasons, etc. might be more appropriate on this one?
Only on JDK 11? Or on all JDKs except JDK 8?
@ebarboni `webcommon/javascript2.jquery` tests fail randomly, could I merge it?
I'm trying to add some unit tests at least for the model.
I've been using this patch in my working IDE without problems for 3 weeks now. I've also tested it on MacOS. Should be safe to merge.
updated to FlatLaf 0.30 to fix rendering of Unicode characters on Windows
@hectorespert , yep go for it
I will wait @jtulach feedback on code rewrite that @sdedic mention
Is conversation over and can this be merged ?
@jkovalsky given conversations elsewhere, should this now be closed to get it off the 12.0 list?

Seems fine to merge.

On the color-the-whole-tab-vs.-just-the-top discussion, feel free to merge whichever one you prefer for now. Easy to revisit later.
Just make sure the Travis tests pass... (the failing ones probably just need to be restarted)
Looks fine once Travis passes.
@matthiasblaesing With my plan to move the Gradle Support out of Groovy beyond 12.0, would it be better to define this module in the IDE cluster right now?

What is the behavior in Javadoc generated by the javadoc tool? Does it do the same?

(One could argue that the superclass description _should_ be included, as the subclass is bound to follow the requirements set there. But I would say, do whatever the behavior of the javadoc tool is.)
This one will need a better commit title and description.
Yes, should add a test here, though I haven't had time to return to this yet. Though this patch has been running without problem in my working IDE and on my platform application for 4 months now.
Moving should be uncritical. It changes location of the module, but not the logical data. We moved some libraries in this cycle.
Travis had time out on testing on Java 11, otherwise passed. I think this one is good to go!
+1 Approved, Thanks
Yes, we can close this one but need to create a different PR for removal of 8.2 update center instead. I will do that.

Hi @jkovalsky 

New URL for NetBeans 12.0 is https://plugins.netbeans.apache.org/data/12.0/catalog.xml.gz

Would it be possible to update it everywhere? There's no need to add a "pluginportal" directory any more.

Thanks,
Antonio

@vieiro for the IDE will need changing in https://github.com/apache/netbeans-website/blob/master/netbeans.apache.org/src/content/.htaccess

Need to liaise with Eric on that change and this - he's missing on review list. Can't add via mobile UI.

Hi @ebarboni , @neilcsmith-net .

I understand that .htaccess has to be changed, but I don't know **what** needs to change. I need to understand the current setup to that I can make the change. 

So, for instance, is
http://plugins.netbeans.org/nbpluginportal/updates/11.0/catalog.xml
Supposed to be changed to
https://plugins.netbeans.apache.org/data/11.0/catalog.xml ?

Maybe we can meet sometime and talk about this? Or explain the current setup so I can be of help?
Travis errors are timeouts on tests.
Hi again @neilcsmith-net , @ebarboni , @jkovalsky if we're dropping plugins.netbeans.org then the redirection is not needed any more, or  is it?

> This one will need a better commit title and description.

Does the original JIRA ticket suffice?
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-3575

The JIRA report is good, we just need a short summary for the git log as well. E.g. use title "[NETBEANS-3575] Fix ordering of j2ee.platform.classpath entires" for the commit title and a shorter summary of the bug in the commit description.

Also check that you have a real name/email in the git commit. (I'm not sure how to check this from the GitHub interface... but I remember we've had trouble with getting this info correct in the past once we merge the PR.)

The code changes look good--thank you!
Yes, I think so @vieiro. We can get rid of it unless it breaks redirection for older NetBeans 9.*, 10.* or 11.*.

-1 to removing the redirection for now. In early video meetings on web infra we discussed having all IDE inbound links under the same path (/nb/*).  It may be less important now as we've almost finished transitioning, but good for consistency, tracking, ease of changing redirects while releases active, etc.

@vieiro @jkovalsky can we have that discussion on dev@ for the 12.1 timeframe rather than changing at this point?
@neilcsmith-net @ebarboni @jkovalsky  I don't know what "early video meetings on web infra ", please send me a link via email so I can join.

@vieiro you were involved - talking 2 years ago now?!  Just saying that having the redirects through the website .htaccess is still potentially useful, and changing just before release doesn't seem the right approach.  Better to discuss / change in next release cycle?

Update centres, plugins and issue reporting links are all managed in one place there, and its documented as such in a few places.  Everything comes in under a netbeans.apache.org/nb/* path too, which has benefits.

@eirikbakke thank you for taking time to review it.

Indeed Javadoc handles it differently. It does not include the Javadoc of a parent method. Also, I checked the Eclipse's tooltip - it doesn't include the parent Javadoc at all.
But in the NetBeans, there is a whole bunch of code to handle it. The bug here is just how NetBeans combines a description of parameters.
Before fixing NetBeans dose it in that way:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1295142/79040991-020f9100-7bf5-11ea-88e6-164c7d7b40f1.png)

i.e for the index it combines Javadoc both from parent and from the current method and does it a little awkwardly.
for the c parameter, it only adds Javadoc from the parent method.

After fixing NetBeans dose it in that way:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1295142/79041291-5b78bf80-7bf7-11ea-8643-f5b6ea516b3e.png)

@eirikbakke   thank you for taking the time to review it. Changed the code accordingly to your comments.
By the way, can I rerun manually Travis tasks? Do I need special rights to rerun it?
Please do not squash-and-merge this - the github account seems not the provide the necessary information.

> The JIRA report is good, we just need a short summary for the git log as well. E.g. use title "[NETBEANS-3575] Fix ordering of j2ee.platform.classpath entires" for the commit title and a shorter summary of the bug in the commit description.
> 
Thank you for the clarification! I've amended the commit in a way you requested.

> Also check that you have a real name/email in the git commit. (I'm not sure how to check this from the GitHub interface... but I remember we've had trouble with getting this info correct in the past once we merge the PR.)
>
I have no idea how to check this, or by checking so I would have no idea what I would be doing :)
But in any case the corresponding git properties should be configured properly. Furthermore GitHub doesn't let me push unless I'm logged in. Obviously I did not try a configuration that does not much the login information.

@matthiasblaesing How do I confirm, in the GitHub interface, whether the right author/email will end up in the git log upon squash-and-merge?

Also, I'm not seeing the usual "restart" button on the Travis tests. Did something change recently?

Regarding the author information: Have a look at the profile page:
On your page your full name and an Emailaddress is listed, on @dmochalov page none of that is present.

For the restart button: Looks as if either github or travis lost access tokens - I was also missing the buttons, logging out of travis and in again fixed it.
@neilcsmith-net , @ebarboni , @jkovalsky Regarding the redirections, I think that should be done on a separate PR on the netbeans-website repo.

The author information is partially ok - the email is present and looks correct, the real name though does not. You can use the git command to see the information:

`git log -n 3`

Shows the last three commits.

This PR must not be squashed, as the author information in the github profile is not public and thus will cause invalid author information on the squashed commit.

> Regarding the author information: Have a look at the profile page:
> On your page your full name and an Emailaddress is listed, on @dmochalov page none of that is present.

@matthiasblaesing  added the info on my profile page.
I thought that info in **.gitconfig** is enough for correct merging:
```
[user]
	name = Dmitry Mochalov
	email = rigthcoder@gmail.com
```

In git history it looks ok:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1295142/79050653-37879f00-7c34-11ea-8666-dff1ee2e6d0c.png)

@dmochalov yes the author information of the commits is totally ok. The problem starts if someone chooses the "Squash and merge" button in github to merge. CLI git uses the author information from the commits to create the merged author information, github uses the information from the profile (at least from my observation) and if that is not public, the squashed commit will hold invalid information.

In this case there are three options:

1. The commits are not squashed (discussing this is more religion, that science)
2. You as the original author squash the commit prior to merging (after review) and the committer merges that
3. The committer does a manual merge with CLI git

Sorry about that, I think I managed to correct the real name issue.

Is it OK if I'd like to keep my email hidden?

If this plugin portal is disabled, then it is going to be hard to for users of Apache NetBeans to install C/C++ support. Until we can provide C/C++ support as part of Apache NetBeans, I suggested to delay the removal of this (disabled) plugin central.
Bug is confirmed to occur on both MacOS and Windows (with and without HiDPI/Retina scaling), and fixed on both.

Sorry, no correct author information is required. For larger contributions the ASF even requires an signed ICLA. For small contributions we are already relaxing the rules, but we still need to be able to determine the author.
The above is true for the git history (although that is public), you can keep your name out of the github profile, to do so see here:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/2061#issuecomment-612475333
Okay, if I configured things properly it should not be hidden.
Maybe too late for 12.0 but I think this may be a low risk, nice simple quick win, if not 12.1 is ok for me as well...

@JaroslavTulach is documenting how to add the UC for those who want C/C++ support that much more difficult than documenting to enable it?  Surely it really depends on how long Oracle plan on keeping it up?
@eirikbakke : Should fix your mentioned issue
Reading through the method, this seems straightforward enough. Thank you!

> @JaroslavTulach is documenting how to add the UC for those who want C/C++ support 
> that much more difficult than documenting to enable it? 

I remember there was a discussion about setting up the 8.2 update center to get the CND support being too complicated. It resulted in @geertjanw's #894 - I am not sure what has changed since then? Apache NetBeans still lacks CND and that is, in my opinion, a potential acceptance barrier. 

> Surely it really depends on how long Oracle plan on keeping it up?

I have no idea. Knowing corporate policies, I can only assume that until Oracle NetBeans 8.2 is officially EOLed, it has to stay around.
BTW what shall we see on those pictures above?
@jlahoda : Simple test added.
@geertjanw  This is my first pull request, so I am not sure why checks have failed. Please review this.
Sorry, I corrected the description. If this is not enough, tell me what else to add

I think this more a bug in FlatLaf than in NB. 

The question is whether the selected tree item should be blue (which means focused) if a popup menu is shown or become gray (which means not focused).

In Windows Explorer and macOS Finder the selection stays blue when a popup menu is shown.
This feels more natural than changing selection from blue to gray on right-click.

I'll check whether I can change this in FlatLaf.

> I think this more a bug in FlatLaf than in NB. > > The question is whether the selected tree item should be blue (which means focused) if a popup menu is shown or become gray (which means not focused). > > In Windows Explorer and macOS Finder the selection stays blue when a popup menu is shown. > This feels more natural than changing selection from blue to gray on right-click. > > I'll check whether I can change this in FlatLaf. I thought this was a mistake, because in IntelliJ IDEA in the IntelliJ Light theme that FlatLaf looks like, the selection is inactive. For example This is also the case with Aqua LAF in JTree with DefaultTreeCellRenderer.

> I am not sure what has changed since then?

@JaroslavTulach this was initiated by @jkovalsky here and on mailing list partly (as I understand) because there isn't a commitment from Oracle to keep the relevant infrastructure for old plugin centre and 8.2 update centre running for full life of NB 12.0 - ie. until at least May 2021.  And potentially (given other changes) put it behind https.

:+1:

Shouldn't this be matched by somewhat similar logic around https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/java/java.source/src/org/netbeans/modules/java/source/JBrowseModule.java#L94 ?
@matthiasblaesing  Thanks for your inputs. This is really helpful.
@matthiasblaesing Updated the pull request with your suggestion.
The fix was tested locally and by an affected user. The change is minimal and only affects the maven indexing.

Thank you for the update. I don't think that `SimpleTitleParser` should implement `AutoCloseable`. I would just pull the `InputStream` creation into the try-with-resource. The `SimpleTitleParser` can be constructed inside the `try` block.
@matthiasblaesing  I have reverted the AutoClosable implementation from SimpleTitleParser.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-4033

done
/bow thanks for this fix. Had no idea how to fix that

> I thought this was a mistake, because in IntelliJ IDEA in the IntelliJ Light theme that FlatLaf looks like, the selection is inactive.

Yes, I see. But IDEA is not perfect  

Done more testing on Linux (GNOME and KDE) and macOS.
The behavior is always that the focused border and selection stays where it is when opening a popup menu or the main menu. Even a Firefox text area (were I currently write this text) keeps the blue focused border when right-clicking on it.

So I changed the behavior in FlatLaf 0.31.
See PR #2094

Thanks @dinix2008 for pointing out this problem.

> > I thought this was a mistake, because in IntelliJ IDEA in the IntelliJ Light theme that FlatLaf looks like, the selection is inactive.
> 
> Yes, I see. But IDEA is not perfect 
> 
> Done more testing on Linux (GNOME and KDE) and macOS.
> The behavior is always that the focused border and selection stays where it is when opening a popup menu or the main menu. Even a Firefox text area (were I currently write this text) keeps the blue focused border when right-clicking on it.
> 
> So I changed the behavior in FlatLaf 0.31.
> See PR #2094
> 
> Thanks @dinix2008 for pointing out this problem.

Thanks!
Not needed, task solved in FlatLaf library
+1 Approved , Thanks for the fix
+1 Approved, Thank you Jan
@ebarboni @matthiasblaesing I've referenced the proper XMLSchema.dtd so that I don't need to have XMLSchema.dtd and datatypes.dtd in the license.info
@jlahoda : Should be considered for 12.0, too?
+1 Approved, thanks for fixing this Akhilesh
There's now an issue in the OpenJDK bug tracker concerning the "line thickness": https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8241561
@problemzebra2 Ah, great!

@errael I'll open a JIRA ticket, but looks like this change breaks the Maven Create Module Action - https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/java/maven/src/org/netbeans/modules/maven/nodes/ModulesNode.java#L334
Well let's rethink the feature!

Thanks for the heads up. The change has the comment
//PROJECT_PARENT_FOLDER confusing, better name is PROJECT_BASE_FOLDER
Rename is an API change. Of course most of the old/ancient code just 
using a literal string "proj.dir" or something like that. Hopefully it's 
usage is pretty local...

I guess some hack for 12.0. I haven't looked yet, maybe a property name 
like "parent.proj.dir" with a suitable CONSTANT is the right idea.

On 4/21/2020 7:52 AM, Neil C Smith wrote:
>
> @errael <https://github.com/errael> I'll open a JIRA ticket, but looks 
> like this change breaks the Maven Create Module Action - 
> https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/java/maven/src/org/netbeans/modules/maven/nodes/ModulesNode.java#L334
>
> 
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub 
> <https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/1980#issuecomment-617229975>, 
> or unsubscribe 
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AE4AY65CQ7F4O5UIKX476NLRNWXK5ANCNFSM4K3PW2CA>.
>

Personally think @matthiasblaesing was right about storing the parent location back in (comment Mar 2). `PROJECT_PARENT_FOLDER` is documented to be and already has the semantics of being the right thing, surely?

Opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-4206

@errael isn't the problem at https://github.com/apache/netbeans/blob/master/java/maven/src/org/netbeans/modules/maven/newproject/BasicPanelVisual.java#L527

It's using `createdFolderTextField` but should be using `projectLocationTextField` to match up with how that stored property is used in read()?

There's `public static final String PROJECT_PARENT_FOLDER = "projdir";` which is probably the root of my considerable confusion. If you grep this, like '"projdir"', it is used as a wizard property key for the directory of the project, not the parent directory (projectLocation).

It may be that this isn't an issue, and that the new/maven CommonProjectActions won't interact with the old stuff that this is a problem. I noticed that the change about lazy directory creation, that it never got invoked in actual use.

Given what "projdir" means in maven, I think you're right. Use `projectLocationTextField`; fix up read as needed. The original problem with read was after the back button when it was re-initializing the gui fields. Should have a PR later today.

Sorry, I don't like it. This introduces a cross-cluster dependency, that is not recorded in the project setup. The benefit is minimal and the potential cost is huge. Loading the file at runtime will also most probably fail, as the relative path does not take into account the runtime location of the files.
There is already a copy of xml.xsd, so I would also include the dtds.
